Posts.Content: Has anyone had microcalcifications? If so, what did your dr suggest you do about them. Thanks
Posts.Title: microcalcifications

Posts.Content: Hi JM....I don't blame you for being concerned about this. I have had only one breast removed, my left one, 4 years ago. I had 15 nodes taken, all negative. My heart goes out to you. I have often thought what would I do if I got cancer in my right breast and nodes were removed. This is a terrible position to be put in. So far, I have not had any swelling. I don't have many comforting words for you. I think I would ask every question I could think of to the surgeon about where to put that IV. Seems like I have read somewhere that they can put it in other places, especially since you have had nodes removed from both sides. I also had a port...and I am so glad I did. I would recommend it to anyone having chemo. But your case is special. I can't comment on what the nurses told you. I know they know more than I do. Having said that, I also know the medical establishment does not take lymphedema questions as seriously as I think it should. Maybe Leo can help more if he reads your post in time. Good Luck to you...you will be in my thoughts and prayers
Posts.Title: Lymphedema phobia???

Posts.Content: Hi Bree...that address for the pink bracelets is www.lymphedema.com I posted it the other day under "lymphedema awareness" I agree with everything you said. Fortunately, I haven't had any swelling in my arm, but I think about it all the time. I get so upset when I read about women who do have it. Why drs don't seem to inform us about it....I WILL NEVER UNDERSTAND THAT. Dr. Leo, my question to you is..."are you going to be vigilent about informing your patients of this potential problem?" My oncologist never mentioned it to me.
Posts.Title: Lymphedema phobia???

Posts.Content: Hi Bree...that address for the pink bracelets is www.lymphedema.com I posted it the other day under "lymphedema awareness" I agree with everything you said. Posts.Title: Lymphedema phobia???

Posts.Content: Hi all....I know exactly what you are talking about when it comes to this subject. NOBODY in the medical field wants to discuss it. Thank god , I have not had any swelling and I am coming up on 4 years post surgery. Did want to mention a site to get PINK bracelets FREE www.lymphedema.com or 1 800 29 EDEMA I wear one whenever I am travelling or have to go to the doctor or in hospital for a procedure. It gets everyones attention. I had appendicitis last year and it came in very handy!!!! Mine says: ALERT LYMPHEDEMA No Blood Tests, Blood Pressure, No I.V. or Injections into this Arm! Good Luck to everyone

Posts.Title: Lymphedema phobia???

Posts.Content: I agree with everyone here about this magazine...it is the BEST. I am of the belief that we need to know all the info we can just in case we need it . I wish I had known more about breast cancer so I could have known the right questions to ask my doctors. I also realize that until you have it or some other terrible disease, you don't know what to ask. I think it is such a scary thing, that we put it out of our minds as long as life is going along ok. I didn't mean to go on and on...really just wanted to comment on the CURE magazine. HAPPY NEW YEAR EVERYBODY!!!!!!!
Posts.Title: In case some of you didn't know about this

Posts.Content: My onc. keeps telling me I do not need to have a mammogram on the reconstructed breast. So, I haven't. I had a skin-sparing mast. on Feb. 6, 2001..with immediate tram flap surgery. I hope she knows what she's talking about. I ask her everytime I go for a check up and her answer is always the same..."THAT IS A RECONSTRUCTED BREAST, AND YOU DO NOT NEED A MAMMOGRAM ON IT."
Posts.Title: mammograms after breast construction?

Posts.Content: Lauri, I know what you mean. This has been a strange winter so far. We had 4 inches of snow the day after Christmas...here in NC. But the past several days, we have been basking in Springtime weather...upper 70s. But things are suppose to return to normal here sometime this weekend. I pray for all the ones lost in these tragic weather stories.
Posts.Title: Hope everyone is surviving winter...m

Posts.Content: I had BC 4 years ago. I have a 33 year old daughter who just had her first baby. She has been told to wait until turning 35 before having a mammogram. Being her Mother, I would feel better if she had one now. What is the right age now for younger women whose Mothers have had BC to get that first mammogram?
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer in Young Women

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for responding to my question about my daughter. I was DX at 52, I am now 56. She is 33. So I guess waiting until she is 35 seems reasonable before she has a screening, that's what her ob/gyn has told her. SEEMS REASONABLE TO EVERYONE BUT ME!!!!!!! I have heard and talked to so many young women that have this horrible disease, and I guess I just want my daughter to do everything she can to catch it early. It seems to me she would be in a much higher risk...mother with breast cancer, having her first baby at age 33...I don't know...I am rambling on and on here...she is not nearly as concerned about it as I am. Thanks again for this site and for all that you do for us.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer in Young Women

Posts.Content: It has been 4 years since my mast. and removal of 15 nodes on my left side. My left arm has always had a "heavy" feeling. My onc. sent me to a PT about a year after my surgery, thinking I had some swelling...I didn't have any. The PT I saw told me she sees lymphedema more in women who are overweight and had radiation. I am not overweight and did not have radiation. Has anyone else been told this? My husband measured my arms Saturday, and there was no swelling. I guess this heavy feeling is a normal thing? I was just wondering if anyone else here has the same feeling I do in their arm..but no swelling. Thanks
Posts.Title: Another Lymphedema ?

Posts.Content: My onc. seems perfectly fine with me having an annual diagnostic mammogram. She never mentions having an ultrasound on my "good" breast. I would feel better having one every 6 months...but does that mean I would be getting too much radiation? I was DX 4 years ago on Oct 30. I could not feel my lump..1.6 cm. I had lump., 4x A/C, mast. and immediate tram flap reconstruction. I want to stay ahead of this game if possible. I can't take meds. because of side effects. I have tried tamoxifen, arimidex, and femara.....NO MORE. She has told me I do not need mammogram on the reconstructed breast. But I have heard from other women who do have it. I am so confused. Thank you so much Dr. Leo for this sight. We women and men need all the info we can get.
Posts.Title: how often to have mammograms

Posts.Content: HAPPY NEW YEAR DR LEO!!!!!!! HERE IS HOPING FOR ALL THE BEST FOR YOU AND YOUR FAMILY IN THE NEW YEAR. THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR THIS SIGHT. THIS IS THE BEST CHRISTMAS PRESENT WE COULD HAVE RECEIVED!!!!! GOD BLESS YOU
Posts.Title: CHEERS and a toast to Dr. Leo!

Posts.Content: Hi...glad to hear you had a great Christmas. We did also. Our daughter, son-in-law(originally from Minnesota) and our 6 month old grandson came. They live in Charlotte now. We live in eastern part of North Carolina and we have snow on the ground!!!! About 4 inches. I am just praying for it to melt soon!!!! God Bless
Posts.Title: Hope everyone had a Merry Christmas....
